EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


1. INTRODUCTION

Chester Water Authority (CWA) owns and operates the Octoraro Water Treatment Plant (Octoraro WTP), which is located in Little Britain Township, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. Waters from the Octoraro Reservoir and the Susquehanna River are treated at this facility to federal and state drinking water standards.  Water pumped from the Octoraro WTP supplies approximately 200,000 customers located in southern Chester and western Delaware County of Pennsylvania as well as northeastern Delaware.

Chlorine gas is used to disinfect the water in the treatment processes at the Octoraro WTP.  If accidentally released to the air in significant quantity, chlorine gas is extremely hazardous.  CWA carefully stores and handles the chlorine it uses at the Octoraro WTP to prevent its accidental release.  

The chlorine gas used at the Octoraro WTP is purchased as a compressed liquefied gas in standard one-ton containers from commercial suppliers. Liquid chlorine from a one-ton container flows to evaporators where the liquid is warmed and converted to a gas.  The chlorine gas is regulated, metered and pulled by vacuum into chemical feed lines that distribute chlorine/water solution to the treatment process. Only one container is in use at any given time.  However, when fully stocked, the Octoraro WTP may have 23 one-ton containers or 46,000 pounds of chlorine on site. This exceeds the threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds established under the RMP regulations. 

This Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) describes the chemical hazards associated with chlorine and explains what CWA is doing to prevent an accidental release.  It has been developed and implemented in accordance with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) and guidelines specifically created for water treatment plants (AWWARF Compliance Guidance and Model Risk Management Program for Water Treatment Plants). CWA's Hazard Assessment, Rele

ase Prevention, and Emergency Response programs for chlorine are described in the following subsections.

The Octoraro WTP also uses ammonia, but the maximum inventory is below the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds; therefore, CWA's ammonia use is not regulated under RMP. 

2  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Chester Water Authority has a policy that addresses its commitment to accident prevention and risk management. This policy reads as follows:

"The Chester Water Authority is committed to protecting its employees, the public, and the environment from accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities.  CWA will implement safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to minimize the risks presented by hazardous materials used at its facilities.  If there is an accidental release, CWA will either provide, or request from others, immediate emergency response to minimize the effect of the release. CWA will also immediately notify the public, through county emergency management agencies, of actions necessary to ensure public protection."

3. WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

CWA has conducted an offsite consequence analysis including a worst-case release scenario.  As required by the RMP regulations, the worst-case scenario is defined as a ten-minute release of the greatest quantity of the regulated substance contained in any single vessel or pipeline.  For CWA's Octoraro WTP, this greatest quantity is the 2,000-pound contents of a standard one-ton chlorine container.  Consequently, the worst-case release is 200 pounds per minute of chlorine for ten minutes.

Although the chlorine is stored and used indoors, which can reduce the rate of release and the potential impact distance, it was conservatively assumed to be released outdoors.  In addition, the regulations require assuming worst-case wind speed and atmospheric conditions that result in the greatest projected impact distance.  A release dispersio

n model is used to project the distance to an "endpoint" concentration of the released compound.  For the offsite consequence analyses required by the RMP regulations, this endpoint concentration is defined by the Emergency Response Planning Guideline (ERPG-2) values developed by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA).  AIHA defines the ERPG-2 value as, "the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action."  The endpoint (ERPG-2 value) established for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L (3 ppm).

For the rural setting of the Octoraro WTP, the potential distance to the endpoint concentration for the worst-case release is 3.0 miles.  This distance was obtained from the American Water Works Association Research Foundation (AWWARF) Compliance Guidance and Model Risk Management Program for Water Treatment Plants and is based on dispersion modeling that meets the RMP requirements for the worst-case release conditions.  Because wind direction varies, a chlorine release could migrate in any direction.  As a result, the area that could be above this concentration is assumed to be a circle with a three-mile radius centered at the Octoraro WTP.  With wind blowing in one direction, modeling predicts that only an oval-shaped area directly downwind of the plant would be impacted.  In an actual release, distance and direction will vary based on actual weather conditions and terrain, because chlorine is a dense gas that flows downhill.

There are approximately 3,600 residents within the three-mile radius for the worst-case scenario based on the area within the circle and 1990 Census data.  However, if the worst-case release occurred, only a portion of these residents, those that are located downwind or down hill of the Octoraro WTP, would be in the aff

ected area.  Low-lying areas, such as the Octoraro Creek, may be more vulnerable and elevated areas less vulnerable than modeling predicts. Other public receptors within the three-mile radius include a small  Amish school, some small-scale commercial operations, several churches and three recreation areas (the Octoraro Reservoir  area, the Pine Grove Covered Bridge area and Girl Scout Camp Tweedale).  There are no hospitals, prisons, or major office or industrial areas within this impact area. There are no environmental receptors (i.e., national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; and Federal wilderness areas) within the impact area.

A major release of the magnitude represented by this worst-case scenario is unlikely because of the design of one-ton containers and the maintenance and prevention programs in place at the Octoraro WTP.  Additionally, release reporting databases and industry experience also indicate that the worst-case release scenario as defined in the RMP regulations is unlikely and  should not be used as the basis for emergency planning.  A more reasonable potential release scenario for emergency planning is presented in Subsection 4 below.

4. ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The alternate release scenario selected was the release of liquid chlorine from the bottom valve of a one-ton container. This scenario was selected from those provided in AWWARF'S Compliance Guidance and Model Risk Management Program for Water Treatment Plants because it represents an accident that is feasible for the Octoraro WTP and because it meets the RMP requirement that the impact distance for the alternate release must extend offsite unless no such scenario exists.  

This alternate release could be caused by several plausible accidents including a container valve failure, or a faulty or improperly connected flexible connection.  This scenario assumes that the valve is wide open and the connectio

n is off, which is the most severe case associated with these potential causes. This would result in releasing a gas and aerosol mixture of chlorine, at a rate of approximately 69 pounds per minute for up to 31 minutes.  Most incidents of this kind involve lower release rates due to partially stuck open valves and/or leaking (not removed) connections. 

For the rural setting of the Octoraro WTP, the potential distance to the endpoint concentration for this alternate release is 1.5 miles. There are approximately 800 residents within this potential impact area; however, only portion of these residents, those that are located downwind of the release, would typically be in the affected area.  Other public receptors within this area include a small Amish school, some small-scale commercial operations, two churches and three recreation areas (the Octoraro Reservoir  area, the Pine Grove Covered Bridge area and Girl Scout Camp Tweedale).  There are no hospitals, prisons, major office or industrial areas or environmental receptors within this impact area.  As with the worst-case scenario, actual distances and directions vary with terrain and weather conditions.

5. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Within the past five years, CWA's Octoraro Water Treatment Plant has not had any accidental chlorine releases that resulted in injuries or damages. Under the RMP regulations, all accidental releases of a regulated substance that "resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage" within the past 5 years must be reported.  

6. PREVENTION PROGRAM

Under the EPA RMP regulations, three levels of prevention program requirements have been established to roughly match the level of effort to the risk of off-site impacts.  Because the offsite consequence analysis showed that the worst-case release scenario could impact offsite public receptors, and because the OSHA

PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119) is not applicable at this facility, CWA's Octoraro WTP must meet RMP Program 2 Prevention Program requirements for its chlorination process.  CWA's Prevention Program is summarized below.

A.  Management System:

CWA has developed a management program that assigns overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Risk Management Program to the Chief of Treatment and Pumping at the Octoraro WTP.  The management program also clearly delineates accountability and responsibility for each of the prevention program elements.

B.  Safety Information:

Up-to-date safety information related to the chlorination process is maintained at the plant and is used by plant operators who are responsible for operating the chlorination system.  It includes the following:
7 Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS's) for chlorine that meet the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.1200(g).  
7 A summary of the maximum intended inventory of the equipment in which the chlorine is stored or processed.
7 Safe upper and lower operating limits (i.e., temperatures, pressures, flows, and compositions) for the chlorination system.
7 Equipment specifications for the chlorination system.
7 A list of the codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the chlorination equipment.
7 A process flow diagram of the chlorination process.
 
 The chlorination equipment at the Octoraro WTP has been reviewed against recognized and accepted good engineering practices and is designed, maintained, inspected, tested, and operated in a safe manner.  The safety information is updated when a major change is made to the process that renders the original information inaccurate.
 
 C. Hazard Review:  
 
 CWA has performed a hazard review of its chlorination system using the WTP Hazard Review Checklist for Simple Chlorine Feed Systems found in the Compliance Guidance and Model Risk Management Program for Water Treatment Plants.  This checklist satisfies the requirements of 40 CF

R 68.50. Safety issues identified during this review have been documented and a schedule has been developed for their resolution.  A copy of the completed hazard review checklist is maintained with the safety information for the Octoraro WTP chlorination system.  In the future, CWA will update this review checklist at least every five years or after any major modification to the chlorination process.  
 
 Prior to CWA's hazard review, a representative of the EPA Region 3 conducted a safety inspection of the chlorination system on December 15, 1994.  The EPA recommended several modifications to improve the safety of the chlorination process and CWA acted to implement many of the recommended modifications.  A follow-up inspection was conducted by the EPA on May 31, 1996.  EPA acknowledged the modifications made, recognized CWA  for its commitment to accidental release prevention and mitigation, and offered additional recommendations for improvements.  Many of these additional recommendations have since been implemented by CWA or are under consideration.
 
 D.  Operating Procedures: 
 
 Detailed and up-to-date operating procedures (OP's) have been developed and are maintained for the chlorination process at the Octoraro WTP in accordance with 40 CFR 68.52.  These OP's provide clear step-by-step instructions for safely conducting activities involving the chlorination process in a manner consistent with the chlorine safety information, and are readily available to all employees responsible for working with the chlorination process.  These OP's are reviewed and updated as necessary prior to startup following any major modifications to the chlorination process.
 
 These OP's cover each operating phase of the chlorination process including normal operations, temporary operations, temporary shutdown, emergency shutdown, and startup following an emergency or temporary shutdown.  The OP's contain special warnings and precautions for any procedures that could be dangerous if pe

rformed incorrectly.  Where appropriate, the OP's identify the consequences of deviating from the standard procedure, and also provide instructions on how to correct or avoid such deviations. 
 
 E.  Training  
 
 All new employees who work with the chlorination system at the Octoraro WTP receive initial training in accordance with 40 CFR 68.54.  The training includes an overview of the chlorination process and equipment and emphasizes standard operating procedures, safe work practices, health and safety hazards, and emergency operations including shutdown.  Those employees already experienced and qualified for operating or maintaining the chlorination system prior to June 21, 1999 have been certified in writing as having "the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities as specified, of chlorination process operating procedures."
 
 Refresher training is provided at a minimum of every 3 years to all employees involved in working with the chlorination process.  Documentation is maintained for each employee to ensure he or she has received and understood the required training.
 
 F.  Maintenance:
 
 A maintenance program for the chlorination system at the Octoraro WTP has been developed in accordance with 40 CFR 68.56.  Employees responsible for the maintenance of the chlorination equipment receive additional training, which includes an overview of the process, its hazards, and applicable procedures to ensure they can perform the job in a safe manner.
 
 Written procedures are used to ensure that the chlorination equipment is properly maintained, tested, and inspected at regularly scheduled intervals and that these activities are thoroughly documented.  Maintenance, inspection, and testing procedures and frequencies are consistent with manufacturer's recommendations and follow accepted engineering practices.  Any equipment deficiencies identified during maintenance, inspection, and testing are corrected in a safe and timely man

ner.
 
 G.  Compliance Audits:
 
 The continued compliance of the Risk Management Program for the chlorination system at the Octoraro WTP is ensured through compliance audits that are performed at least once every three years in accordance with 40 CFR 68.58.  The plant's Chief of Treatment and Pumping completes the audits with the assistance of those who operate and maintain the chlorination process.  A report of the findings is generated following the audit and deficiencies and/or recommendations are addressed and the resolution is documented.  The two most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained at the facility.
 
 H.  Incident Investigation:
 
 Specific incident investigation, reporting, and documentation procedures have been implemented and are adhered to, in accordance with 40 CFR 68.60, in response to any incident involving a regulated process that did or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Under EPA RMP, a catastrophic release is defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.
 
 The incident investigation procedure is initiated as soon as possible and no later than 48 hours following any incident.  A team is then established to perform the incident investigation that includes the Chief and Assistant Chief of Treatment and Pumping, the Operations Supervisor, the Electrical/Mechanical Supervisor and an independent third party (if available) with appropriate qualifications to investigate an accident.  Following the investigation, a written report is prepared summarizing the following information: date of the incident; date the investigation began; description of the incident; contributing factors; and recommendations resulting from the investigation.  When completed, plant personnel who operate or maintain the process, review the report.  Incident investigati

on reports are maintained at the facility for a minimum of 5 years. 
 
 7.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
 
 CWA's Octoraro WTP has an emergency response plan addressing the EPA RMP-regulated chlorination system operated at the facility.  
 
 CWA's emergency response plan contains:
7 Emergency notifications required by the facility's SARA Title III Off-Site Response Plan, which was developed by the Lancaster County LEPC. Procedures. Agencies notified directly by CWA include the Lancaster County Emergency Management Agency, Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency and the National Response Center.
7 Evacuating of non essential plant personnel from immediate plant area and sheltering at another plant location that is at a higher elevation and normally upwind from the chlorine building.
7 Coordination with emergency responders by qualified plant personnel.
 
 8. SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS
 
 In CWA's ongoing effort to improve safety and reduce the risk of accidental releases at the Octoraro WTP, the following changes to the RM Program and the facility have been implemented or are currently planned.  These improvements were identified as risk reduction measures during the hazard review or EPA inspection of the WTP chlorination system, or were the result of CWA's desire to develop an improved RM Program and an inherently safer process.
